page.title: 02Hawton Church
page.content: Hawton was in existence before the Roman conquest. It is also mentioned in the Domesday Book when it must have been much larger. It used to have two churches, but only one remains. The church is known as All Saints. The oldest part of the church is the north arcade of three arches which date back to 1280. The style is Early English. The chancel was built by, or in memory of, the second Sir Robert de Compton who died in 1330. Over the founder's tomb is the mutilateed effigy of Sir Robert in chainmail. The East window was built about 1330 in Curvilinear style and is one of the finest large windows of the period. There is an Easter Sepulchre in which Christ' Ressurection is depicted. The tower is a three stage tower, built by Sir Thomas Molyneax who died in 1491.
